facts.text: Four informations lodged at police station Ghora Saha on April 14, 1960 by different persons against different appellants alleging each set of accused armed with deadly weapons went to shops of informants, demanded large sums of money, threatened death if not paid.
Some informants paid part of money and given time to pay balance, some agreed to pay demanded amounts.
Offences under s.392 IPC registered, after investigation five challans lodged in Court of Magistrate First Class at Motihari. One case ended in acquittal.
In other four cases, trial proceeded: all prosecution and defence witnesses examined, cases closed for judgment.

In case against appellants in Crl. A. 165/1962, challan presented October 27, 1960. Charges framed: u/s 302 IPC against Thakur Ram and Jagarnath Pd.; separate charges u/s 384 IPC against Jagarnath, Kamal Ram, Bansi Ram; u/s 384/109 against Thakur Ram. Pleas not guilty.

Trial dragged on for nearly 15 months. Prosecution applied January 25, 1962 for framing charge u/s 386 or 387 IPC and committing to Sessions Court. Magistrate refused, noting case in defence stage, point not raised before, charge already framed u/s 392 after hearing parties.
February 28, 1962, prosecution petition for stay to file revision refused, case proceeded.
March 17, 1962 defence closed, fixed for arguments March 29, 1962.
March 29, 1962 second application for commitment to Sessions. Ordered for next day.
March 30, 1962 Magistrate rejected prayer, finding not exclusively under s.386/387 IPC.
Revision filed not by prosecution but by Sagarmal (informant in another case) to Sessions Judge, Champaran. Sessions Judge directed commitment to Sessions Court.

Appellants filed revision to Patna High Court against Sessions Judge order, main ground no jurisdiction under s.437 CrPC without order of discharge. High Court dismissed revisions on August 25, 1962, holding refusal to frame s.386/387 charge amounted to discharge.
Certificate for appeal to SC rejected, appellants came by special leave.

legal_issues.text: Whether under s.437 Cr.P.C., Sessions Judge can direct commitment to Sessions Court in absence of express order of discharge by Magistrate, when trial before Magistrate is proceeding for offences not exclusively triable by Sessions.
Whether Sessions Judge properly exercised discretion under s.437 Cr.P.C. to order commitment at late stage of trial.

petitioner_arguments.text: Sessions Judge had no jurisdiction to pass order for commitment as there was no order of discharge by Magistrate.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.437 Cr.P.C.; Nahar Singh v. State (Allahabad Full Bench); Sri Dulap Singh v. State; Yunus Shaikh v. State

petitioner_arguments.text: Refusal to commit or frame higher charge does not amount to implied discharge attracting s.437.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Provisions of Cr.P.C. requiring express discharge

respondent_arguments.text: Cases serious, framing charges u/s 386/387 IPC cannot be ruled out; Magistrate's refusal to frame such charges amounted to final order of discharge.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.386/387 IPC; s.437 Cr.P.C.; in re Nalla Baligadu (Madras Full Bench)

court_reasoning.text: Powers under s.437 Cr.P.C. exercisable not only on express discharge but also where Magistrate refuses/omits to commit for Sessions-triable offence, as failure to commit does not amount to implied discharge precluding revision; otherwise provisions defeated.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Magistrate's refusal to frame higher charge or commit amounts to discharge for that offence, attracting s.437.

court_reasoning.text: Analysed ss.207, 207A, 347 Cr.P.C.: Magistrate can discharge if no ground for commitment, or proceed to try lesser offence; but revision lies to prevent Magistrate encroaching on Sessions jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prima facie case assessment by Magistrate not final weighing of evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Dissent from Allahabad view; agree with Madras Full Bench; Magistrate power to commit at any stage u/s 347 does not preclude revision on refusal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.437 wide, exercisable during pendency of trial.

court_reasoning.text: High Court right on jurisdiction, but Sessions Judge injudicious in ordering commitment: prosecution belated (15 months, defence closed, arguments heard, closed for judgment); revision by private informant not prosecution; harassment to accused.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Discretion under s.437 judicial, consider stage of proceedings, locus.

holdings.text: Sessions Judge has jurisdiction under s.437 Cr.P.C. to direct commitment even without express order of discharge by Magistrate if refusal to commit amounts to discharge for Sessions-triable offence.
Discretion under s.437 must be exercised judicially; improper at late trial stage causing harassment, especially on private party's revision.

precedents_cited.relevance: Allahabad Full Bench held s.437 only on express discharge.
Not on lack of jurisdiction but improper discharge.
Madras Full Bench: revision under s.437 before conclusion of trial even under s.209.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rambalam Pd. Singh v. State of Bihar
Ramgopal Ganpatrai v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Magistrate satisfied prima facie case for commitment.
Refusal to commit equals discharge for higher offence.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences of robbery, extortion, dacoity; Magistrate framed lesser charges, refused higher.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Revision and commitment powers; procedure on police report for Sessions cases; power to commit at any stage.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held Sessions Judge had jurisdiction under s.437 Cr.P.C. to direct commitment without express discharge, affirming High Court on that point, but found Sessions Judge injudiciously exercised discretion given belated prosecution applications, advanced trial stage, and private party's revision, implying setting aside commitment orders.
outcome.relief_granted: Direction that commitment was injudicious; appeals govern similar cases.

key_quotes.text: "The refusal by the Magistrate to frame a charge under section 386 or 387 of the Indian Penal Code was a final order and it amounted to an order of discharge of the accused of the offence under those sections."
key_quotes.speaker: high_court
key_quotes.significance: High Court's basis for upholding jurisdiction.

key_quotes.text: "Express orders of discharge are not required to be passed by the Court in cases where, upon the same facts, it is possible to say that though no offence exclusively or appropriately triable by a Court of Sessions Judge is made out, an offence triable by a Magistrate is nevertheless made out."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on implied discharge under s.437 Cr.P.C.

key_quotes.text: "It would be a terrible harassment to the appellants not to be called upon to face a fresh trial right from the beginning which would certainly be the result if the Magistrate were to commit the appellants for trial by a Court of Sessions now."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justification for criticizing discretion due to trial stage.

key_quotes.text: "The criminal law is not to be used as an instrument of wreaking private vengeance by an aggrieved party against the person who, according to that party, had caused injury to it."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: On locus of private informant in prosecution case.
